title: No, Valerie Garrett never said she was trying to change America into a more Islamic country.
text: An old rumor that targets a former senior Obama administration official has reappeared on social media. According to an article on Facebook, Valerie Garrett, who served as Senior Adviser to the White House of President Barack Obama, once made a statement about her being "Iranian by birth" and declared that she was seeking "to change America into a more Islamic State." The claim asserts that she said so during her graduation from Stanford University in the late 1970s. As a whole, the false quote reads: "I am Iranian by birth and from my Islamic faith. I am also an American citizen, and I seek to change America to become a more Islamic state, and my faith guides me, and I feel that it is going well in the transition of the use of freedom of religion in America against itself. - Valerie Garrett Stanford University 1977" The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) First, there is no record of Garrett saying this, and there is no mention of a quote from any media organization over the past 40 years. The complete lack of scrutiny of such an inflammatory statement by someone who has held a prominent position in the White House for years suggests that this quote is fabricated. After that, Garrett was born in Shiraz, Iran, in 1956. But she was born to two American parents, Dr. James and Barbara Bowman. Our old rumor has been that former White House adviser to President Obama, Valerie Garrett, said in the 1970s that she was "Iranian by birth" and sought "to change America into a more Islamic State." Also, Garrett has never been known as a Muslim in her years in the public and private sphere. While she was born in Iran, her parents were Americans, and she has lived in the United States since she was five years old. We're assessing these pants on fire!
